description.narrative:
EBRD har ansökt om 24 miljoner kronor från Sveriges ambassad i Sarajevo för att medfinansiera det regionala vattenförsörjningsprojektet ”Plava Voda” för perioden 2016-2018. Projektet syftar till att förbättra levnadsvillkoren för befolkningen samt att stödja Bosnien och Hercegovina (BiH) i ansträngningar att uppfylla EU: s dricksvattendirektivet (Drinking Water Directive) genom att erbjuda en långsiktig lösning gällande vattenförsörjning i fem (5) kommuner . Plava Voda är det första regionala vattenförsörjningsprojektet i Bosnien och Hercegovina som ska göra det möjligt för fem kommuner: Travnik, Novi Travnik, Vitez, Busovaca och Zenica, med sammanlagd befolkning på cirka 250.000, att säkra ytterligare mängder av välbehövlig dricksvatten samt säkerställa en långsiktig lösning för vattenförsörjning av sina invånare. Syftet med "Plava Voda" -projektet är att utvidga utnyttjandet av vatten från Plava Voda vattenkälla som ligger i staden Travnik (som för närvarande används i begränsad omfattning för den lokala vattenförsörjningen), till ytterligare tre kommuner i Central Bosnien Kanton (Novi Travnik, Vitez och Busovaca), liksom staden Zenica, i grann Zenica-Doboj Kanton. Det finns en stor efterfråga på ren och effektiv vattenleverans i de ovan nämnda kommunerna.
Projektet samfinansieras från EBRD lån på 11 miljoner EUR, Europarådets utvecklingsbank (CEB) till ett belopp av ytterligare 11,0 miljoner EUR, samt Sveriges ambassad. Det svenska bidraget på 24 MSEK skall bidra till en institutionell förstärkning av kommunala vattenverk och en minskning av oacceptabelt höga vattenförluster i de fem mottagande kommunerna. Detta skulle komplettera och förbättra den ekonomiska lönsamheten av kommunernas stora investeringar i Plava Voda:s regionala vattenförsörjningsprojekt, men kommer också att bidra till miljöförbättringar och en minskning av hälsorisker.
EBRD kommer att ansvara för administration och förvaltning av svenska medel. Anskaffande av konsulter och entreprenörer kommer att ske i enlighet med EBRD: s upphandlingspolicy och regler för den offentliga sektorn.

EBRD has applied to the Embassy of Sweden in Sarajevo for funding of 24 million SEK to co-finance the regional water supply project Plava Voda during the period 2016-2018. The intervention aims to support the improvement of the existing living conditions of the population bas well as to support Bosnia and Herzegovina in its efforts to comply with the EU Drinking Water Directive by providing a long-term solution to water supply for citizens in 5 project municipalities. Plava Voda is the first regional water supply project in Bosnia and Herzegovina which will enable five municipalities Travnik, Novi Travnik, Vitez, Busovaca and Zenica, with a total population of about 250,000, to secure additional quantities of much needed potable water ensuring a long term solution to water supply for its citizens. The aim of “Plava Voda” project is to extend water exploitation from the Plava Voda spring, located in the town of Travnik (which currently uses it to a limited extent for local water supply), to serve other three municipalities in the Central Bosnia Canton (Novi Travnik, Vitez and Busovaca), as well as the town of Zenica, in the neighbouring Zenica-Doboj Canton. There is a high demand for clean and efficient supply of water in the above mentioned municipalities.
The Project is co-financed by EBRD loan of EUR 11.0 million, CEB in amount of another EUR 11.0 million and Embassy of Sweden. The Swedish contribution of 24MSEK shall provide for institutional strengthening of public utilities and reduction of unacceptably high water losses in 5 beneficiary municipalities, thus maximizing the benefits of high quality water supplies from the Plava Voda Regional Water Supply Project. In that regard, the Swedish contribution shall finance the technical assistance for improvement of institutional&technical capacity of the Public Utility Companies in efficient management and better operational performance, but also investment support for necessary reduction of water losses and subsequent upgrades. This would complement and improve the economic viability of major investments in the Plava Voda Regional Water Supply Project by the municipalities, but will also contribute to environmental improvements and reduction of Health hazards.
EBRD will be responsible for administering and management of Swedish funds. Procurement of consultants and contractors will be done in accordance with EBRD’s Procurement Policies and Rules for public sector

The overall objective of the project is to support the improvement of the existing living conditions of the population in Centracl Bosnia, as well as to support Bosnia and Herzegovina in its efforts to comply with the EU Drinking Water Directive by providing a long-term solution to water supply for citizens in 4 project municipalities. The purpose of the Project is to extend water exploitation from the Plava Voda spring, located in the town of Travnik (which currently uses it to a limited extent for local water supply), to serve three other municipalities in the Central Bosnia Canton (Novi Travnik and Busovaca), as well as the municipality of Zenica, in the neighbouring Zenica-Doboj Canton. There is a high demand for clean and efficient supply of water in the above-mentioned municipalities, especially in Zenica. Thus, the ultimate aim of the Plava Voda Regional Water Supply System project is to satisfy the needs of concerned population by providing reliable long term water supply through joint effort of the involved Municipalities, the Cantons and the Fund.

description.narrative: The annual report have been delivered on time and is complete in terms of fulfilling conditions stipulated in the Agreement. However, the report is very brief in information of which some are even outdated. Below the summary of progress achieved during 2020: In the report project is rated ”Partly unsatisfactory”. The project start has been delayed for years due to delays in declaring EBRD`s loan effective. The loan was finally declared effective on 2 July 2019 after delays of several years in obtaining all the approvals from all the required levels. Following that, the Embassy of Sweden has communicated with EBRD its decision to cancel the investment grant if: 1) The FOPIP and Supervision consultant for leak repairs and NRW measures are to be selected by 31 December 2019 at latest and 2 ) the tender for all lead repair works and NRW measures is to be launched by 31 December 2019. Two conditions set above were not fulfilled by the set deadline, however some progress have been noted at beginning of 2020 and Sweden decided to extend the completion deadline of the grant component until the end of 2022, with expected tender completion for FOPIP consultant in July 2020 and launching leak repairs works tender by end of year 2020. Unfortunately, these two deadlines have not been met in 2020 either. The last availability date for EBRD’s loan had expired in February 2021, however BIH have not met condition for declaring loan effectiveness by that deadline. Following a request and a number of assurances from BIH counterparts, EBRD has decided to approve one more extension until April 2022. EBRD still need to agree with BIH counterparts on a key milestones to be met in order to reach effectiveness of EBRD and CEB loans. Only after declaring effectiveness of EBRD loan, Swedish grant can become operational. Tender for procuring the TC grant funded consultant is still ongoing. The EBRD will continue to follow the project entities, but the EBRD, CEB and Sweden remains concerned about the slow progress of the project. No disbursements from grant funds took place yet. PO`s assessment is that EBRD`s annual report could be of better quality, however Embassy is kept informed through regular contacts with EBRD office in Sarajevo.
